data.text:
🔎 If you're using v2 full-archive search for Academic Research, you won't want to miss this livestream hosted by our research dev advocate @suhemparack.

Mark your calendars to join us on https://t.co/GrtBOXyHmB Thursday March 18th, 10AM PT/ 1PM ET. https://t.co/SpuOoD7Dm8

data.text:
On Tuesday at 12 pm EST, @jessicagarson will cover how to start working with the data returned from v2 of the #twitterapi  

She'll be focusing on how to work with nested JSON and sending your data to a CSV. 

Join us on Twitch!
https://t.co/GrtBOXyHmB

data.text: “I have been a developer from a young age,” says @yesnoornext. @marie_dm_ “started coding in engineering school, where I discovered a strong interest in tech. We always wanted to create something that can help people to follow things they love and save information that matters.”

users.description: The voice of the #TwitterDev team and your official source for updates, news, and events, related to the #TwitterAPI.

users.description: Developer Advocate @Twitter. Python programmer.  Noted thought leader on vegan snacks. Makes music as Messica Arson.

tweets.text:
🚨 Approved for the Academic Research product track on the #TwitterAPI v2?

We have a live-stream coming up - Thursday, March 18th, 1:00 pm EST (on Twitch)

We'll explore the full-archive search endpoint v2 & learn how to get historical data for research

https://t.co/I3keKceIRG

urls.title: Upcoming virtual events
urls.description: We have a few upcoming events on our TwitterDev Twitch channel. These events are typically live-coded samples, live tutorials, and other showcases. Getting started with the Academic Research product track Thursday, February 25th, 1:00 pm EST. If you are newly approved for the Academic Research product track, this session will help you get started. We will answer some of the most common questions about how to use the Academic Research product track, and demo making your first API call to full-...

tweets.text: “The idea of Threader came from the desire to highlight the amazing stories and knowledge shared on Twitter,” explain @marie_dm_ and @yesnoornext. “As threads became popular, they were hard to find or read. We decided to build an app to retrieve and save this great content.”
